snippet: A slightly longer-run perspective offsets some short-run gloom, but the numbers suggest the economy is slowing.
abstract: The Upshot; latest employment report, which shows employers added meager 38,000 jobs in May even as unemployment rate fell to 4.7 percent, could be overstating extent of overall economic slowdown; data suggests broad outlook for economy is not rosy, but is by no means terrible.

byline.contributor: Justin Wolfers is a professor of economics and public policy at the University of Michigan. Follow him on Twitter at @justinwolfers.

lead_paragraph: A slightly longer-run perspective offsets some short-run gloom, but the numbers suggest the economy is slowing.

headline.print_headline: Raw Jobs Data  May Be Overstating  Extent of Slowdown
headline.main: The Jobs Report Is Not Quite as Terrible as It Looks
